awd_titl_txt: Rocky Mountain Scholars Program: Determining the Impact of Cohort-Based Undergraduate Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the national need for well-educated scientists, mathematicians, engineers, and technicians by supporting the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Colorado State University, a public, Land Grant Institution.  Over its five-year duration, this project will fund two-year scholarships to 60 students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in Mathematics and/or Biology. These students will participate in research experiences under the direction of faculty mentors to solve engaging, real-world problems. The project includes a research study that will examine how different approaches to faculty-mentored research experiences affect student performance, graduation rates, and career goals. The broader impacts of this project include further developing the pipeline of high-ability community college students who transition into leadership roles in their fields. The research findings of this program will be widely disseminated for the broad benefit of college educators throughout the nation. 
  
The overall goal of this project is to increase STEM degree completion of low-income, high-achieving undergraduates with demonstrated financial need. The Rocky Mountain Scholars Project will work with an alliance of community colleges to: 1) Recruit  four cohorts of 15 transfer students who meet the financial need, high-ability criteria; 2) Provide the Scholars with scholarship funding; 3) Engage Scholars in faculty-mentored research assistantships; and 4) Provide Scholars with a support program centered on student engagement. The project research plan includes an efficacy study examining whether cohort-based mentored research experiences are more effective than individual mentored-research experiences, with regard academic performance, retention, STEM persistence, decision to enter graduate school, and decision to enter STEM careers. Moreover, it will investigate how the quality and quantity of student interactions with cohort mates and faculty mentors influence these outcomes. The research will consist of a mixed methods approach including: 1) statistical analyses using data obtained from program-generated variables as well as data from Institutional Research and the Analytics Section of the Career Center; 2) surveys and self-efficacy analyses to elicit a holistic picture of students' perceptions of the program's efficacy. Results of this project will be published in STEM education journals, posted on the program web site, and presented at conferences. This project is funded by NSF's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics program, which seeks to increase the number of low-income academically talented students with demonstrated financial need who earn degrees in STEM fields. It also aims to improve the education of future STEM workers, and to generate knowledge about academic success, retention, transfer, graduation, and academic/career pathways of low-income students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the NSF S-STEM Rocky Mountain Scholars Program (RMSP) at Colorado State University was to increase the number of highly talented but economically disadvantaged STEM students who graduate with STEM degrees and to facilitate their progression into STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The RMSP emphasized the recruitment of diverse cohorts including participation of groups that are underrepresented in STEM disciplines. Overall, 43.8% of the participants identified as students of color. The recruitment and participation of students of color was more than twice the overall percentage of students of color at the institution and it was over three times the overall percentage of students of color enrolled in STEM disciplines at the institution.

Over the five-year period of the program, 80 low-income STEM students participated. Of those, 67 have graduated with STEM degrees, 12 are still actively pursuing STEM degrees, and only 1 left the program. All those who are actively pursuing STEM degrees are in good academic standing and on schedule to graduate in spring 2025. Participants have had a 98.8% rate of retention. Among the 98.8% retained, participants have had a 100% rate of persistence in their STEM programs. Of the 67 participants who have graduated, 94% have either elected to pursue a STEM graduate degree or have entered the STEM workforce. Specifically, 35 are employed in STEM careers, 15 are pursuing graduate degrees in biological sciences, 9 are pursuing graduate degrees in biological engineering, 4 are pursuing graduate degrees in chemistry, and only 4 are employed in non-STEM careers.

The programs efficacy study compared the impacts of student participation in cohort-based research to more traditional, individually mentored research experiences, based on key indicators of academic performance, retention, STEM persistence, entry into graduate STEM programs and entry into STEM careers. The findings, to date, show significantly more positive impacts of cohort-based research experiences.

The Intellectual Merits of this project included the creation of a high impact scholarship program that supported a diverse population of students in STEM disciplines, with an emphasis on intensive research projects in advanced settings.  As part of the program, a research study was conducted on cohort-based experiential learning as a means for improving student outcomes and entry into the STEM workforce. Outcomes from this program have been presented at local, regional and national STEM education meetings as well as a regional diversity conference.  Findings of the STEM education research component are being drafted for publication in a peer-reviewed journal. Participants have acknowledged support from this program in dozens of research symposia presentations as well as published journal articles.

The Broader Impacts of this project were built upon existing infrastructure to recruit and nurture cohorts of low-income, traditionally underserved STEM students, who, with faculty mentoring provided in the Rocky Mountain Scholars Program, transition into future leaders in both STEM industry and education. The research findings of this program are being widely disseminated for the broad benefit of STEM educators and the outcomes of the programs research element have contributed to the development of a model for improving the quality and positive impacts of the mentored research experience in STEM education.

 


Last Modified: 01/23/2025
Modified by: Mark Brown
